They do not align with my personal values and I know this to be the case for many of you as well.” Some of the staff members also said that they received emails asking them to explain their absence from the event following Benioff’s remarks, adding to frustration.Beyond the jokes, employees are pushing for something more concrete. The open letter, first reported by Wired, calls on Benioff to issue a public statement condemning what it describes as ICE's "unconstitutional conduct" and to draw clear "red lines" barring the use of Salesforce's cloud and AI products for immigration enforcement. It specifically flags leaked documentation showing Salesforce pitched its Agentforce AI technology to help ICE rapidly hire 10,000 new agents and process tip-line reports.The letter also references the recent killings of Renee Good and Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, calling them a "devastating indictment of a system that has discarded human decency."Salesforce has not responded to multiple requests for comment about Benioff’s jokes or the decision to edit them out of the recording.
Article Summary: Salesforce employees are circulating an internal open letter urging CEO Marc Benioff to publicly denounce US Immigration and Customs Enforcement. During his opening keynote at Salesforce's annual Company Kickoff on Tuesday, BenIOff asked employees who had traveled from outside the US to stand up. He then quipped that ICE agents were in the building keeping tabs on them.

Article Title: Four promises Elon Musk made to xAI employees after co-founders Tony Wu and Jimmy Ba announced their resignation
Article Text:
Elon Musk held an all-hands meeting with xAI employees hours after co-founders Tony Wu and Jimmy Ba announced their exits—the fifth and sixth from the 12-person founding team. Instead of addressing the departures head-on, Musk pitched a lunar satellite factory, a self-sustaining Moon city, a path to 1 billion daily active X users, and a company restructuring into four product teams. The meeting was later posted publicly on X.

Musk wants to build an AI satellite factory on the Moon

A self-sustaining lunar city before Mars

X is gunning for 1 billion daily active users

xAI is being restructured into four product teams

Elon Musk held an all-hands meeting with xAI employees on Tuesday night, just hours after co-founders Yuhuai (Tony) Wu and Jimmy Ba announced they were leaving the company. What followed was a 45-minute presentation that veered from product updates to lunar manufacturing plants.The meeting came at a sensitive moment. Wu and Ba are the fifth and sixth members of xAI's 12-person founding team to walk out the door, with five departures in the past year alone. Rather than dwell on the exits, Musk used the stage to lay out a series of ambitious promises for the company's future.The headline promise was a lunar facility that would manufacture AI-powered satellites and launch them into deep space using electromagnetic catapults, or "mass drivers." Musk painted a picture of satellites firing off the Moon's surface one after another, beaming data back to Earth or running compute locally. "You have to go to the moon," he told employees. He described the Moon's low gravity, lack of atmosphere, and constant solar exposure as ideal conditions for this kind of infrastructure.Musk also outlined a stepping-stone approach to his long-standing Mars obsession. First, xAI and SpaceX would establish what he called "a self-sustaining city on the moon," then push outward to Mars, and eventually to other star systems.He even floated the idea of finding "remnants of ancient alien civilizations" along the way.Back on Earth, Musk shared that X currently has around 600 million monthly active users and set a target of "well over a billion" daily active users. To get there, the company is planning new features including X Money, a banking tool, and a standalone chat app. Nikita Bier, X's head of product, added that the platform had just crossed $1 billion in annual recurring revenue from subscriptions.Musk acknowledged the co-founder departures as part of a broader reorganisation. The company is now split into four teams: Grok (the chatbot), a coding division, the Imagine video generator, and a project called Macrohard—described as a system that can "do anything on a computer that a computer is able to do." Toby Pohlen, who will lead Macrohard, told colleagues the goal is to have "rocket engines fully designed by AI. "The all-hands was later published as a video on X, possibly in response to The New York Times reporting details from the meeting earlier that evening. SpaceX completed its acquisition of xAI last week in a deal valuing the combined entity at $1.25 trillion, with an IPO expected as early as June.
Article Summary: Elon Musk held an all-hands meeting with xAI employees on Tuesday night. Co- founders Tony Wu and Jimmy Ba announced they were leaving the company. Wu and Ba are the fifth and sixth members of xAI's 12-person founding team to walk out the door.

Article Title: Instagram head Adam Mosseri reveals he gets $900,000 a year, says was never worried about ban on beauty filters impacting …
Article Text:
About the social media addiction trial against Meta, YouTube and others

Adam Mosseri on Instagram’s beauty filters

Social media addiction

CEO pay and profits

Instagram head Adam Mosseri became the first tech executive to testify in a landmark social media addiction trial against Instagram parent company Meta, YouTube and others alleging app's design fuels social media action in youth. During the trial Mosseri said that he does not think users can be "clinically addicted” to social media. He was also grilled about his pay, stating that he is paid around $900,000 a year. Additionally he gets rewarded with stock-based compensation and annual performance-based bonuses that can be as high as half of his salary. In a Los Angeles state court, Mosseri revealed that his stock-based pay varies year to year but that it has been in the "tens of millions of dollars."Filed by a 20-year-old woman who is identified by the initials KGM. The lawsuit alleges the social media platform’s addictive design features, including endless scrolling, aggravated her depression and suicidal thoughts.The lawsuit is the first of more than 1,500 similar cases to go to trial. Mosseri is the first executive to testify in a series of trials in which hundreds of families and school districts have sued Meta, Snap, TikTok and YouTube.Adam Mosseri became head of Instagram in 2018. A major focus of the questioning was Instagram’s use of beauty filters that alter facial features. Lawyers referenced internal Meta documents from 2019 that discussed potential harm from such filters, including concerns about body image issues among young users.Mosseri said Instagram initially decided to ban all face-distorting filters but later revised the policy. Filters that promoted cosmetic surgery were banned, he said, while other appearance-altering filters were no longer actively recommended.When asked whether banning filters could have hurt Mosseri's bottom line by limiting the company's growth, he said: “I was never worried about this affecting our stock price”.During questioning, Mosseri said he did not think addiction to Instagram was possible in a clinical sense, though he acknowledged that “problematic use” could occur. He compared excessive use of Instagram to watching television for longer than intended. Mosseri said usage patterns vary by individual and confirmed that he is not a medical professional.Lawyers for the plaintiff highlighted claims that Instagram’s features were designed to keep young users engaged. When asked about a case where the plaintiff allegedly spent more than 16 hours on Instagram in a single day, Mosseri described the behaviour as problematic use. He denied claims that Instagram targets teens to increase profits, saying the company earns less revenue from teenage users than from other age groups.During the trial, lawyers suggested decisions on product features could be linked to company growth and executive pay. Mosseri denied that his decisions were influenced by stock price or personal compensation. He said he was not concerned about how product changes might affect Meta’s financial performance.
Article Summary: Instagram head Adam Mosseri became the first tech executive to testify in a landmark social media addiction trial against Instagram parent company Meta. Mosseri revealed that his stock-based pay varies year to year but that it has been in the "tens of millions of dollars" The lawsuit alleges the social media platform’s addictive design features, including endless scrolling, aggravated her depression and suicidal thoughts.
